42.description: I hope people realize what this is prior to visiting.  This is a flea market.  Not sure how I can make that more clear but you shouldn't expect some 'hipster street fair' as one Yelper wanted (I hope they were as embarrassed writing that as I was to read it, I mean seriously there is an entire documentary made about the history of this, just educate yourself).  There is a ton of historical significance to this gathering of residents from all of the world.  This was referred to as the Ellis Island of the midwest for a reason.  The stuff they sell may not be high quality but it's how people historically were able to obtain things when they didn't have enough money to go to malls and such.  This was the point.  This isn't some new phenomenon created to satisfy someone's hipster appetite; this is and was the livelihood of some of our fellow citizens.  Despite the two moves it has endured, it has evolved into more of a modern day swap meet with some great, authentic food options families have brought over from their native countries to share with us.That being said, I too primarily go for the food.  I did get a pound of dried chiles today but other than that just walked around and ate.  As most people say, Rubis is the place to go.  Honestly it's the best taco I've ever had anywhere.  There is a reason this tiny little stand in an outside market has gotten attention of quite a few famous chefs and food personalities.  The red sauce that's on the table, I was considering what I could dump some in so I could take it home!  I got the beef and cactus and it was to die for.  My husband got the mole and he was in love.  We also went to the stand where they have the pork on a spit like a gyro (which is apparently the truly authentic way to cook the pork) and it was definitely solid.  Of course get a chocolate churro from the Rick Bayless truck as well as a Mexican Coke and how is that not a great day?  The tacos get 10 stars but since I'm reviewing the total experience, gotta go with 4.  :)

23.description: Definitely worth checking out for local street eats and flea market merchandise.The foods are overwhelmingly Mexican, cheap, and tasty. Street vendor like food. It's not for everyone.The merchandise has some garbage (e.g., used shoes) and some pretty good deals. Caveat emptor as pretty much everything is sold as-is where-is.

47.description: If they have it, it's cheap. Also, some of the best antojitos in Chicago.

8.description: I had never been here before and visited the market in July for the first time with my girlfriend. She had been here before. I instantly loved the market. A lot of good food vendors and they're not expensive at all. We ate a bit first and then checked out some other merchandise vendors. All in all I had a great time and would visit again. Very friendly laid back vibe. I wouldn't recommend going there for anything other than food though.

31.description: Nothing to do on a sunny Sunday morning/early afternoon?  Head over to Maxwell Street Market.  The bf and I have been coming here every now and then for the past year to year and a half and it's awesome.  We went this past Sunday and it seemed like there were a couple of vendors that we loved going to that were sadly no longer there.  But, alas!  There are many other great vendors with tamales, tacos, flautas, and much more.I went to a vendor that had elote and a sweet deal of 3 pork tacos for $5.  Add a large horchata and everything was $10.  A more than filling meal for $10?  Yes, please!Also, there's plenty of nick-nacks to browse through if you're looking to work off all the food you ate.Go here if you're looking for some authentic Mexican food, the hustle and bustle of people looking for good eats, or just want something to pass the time!

34.description: The food was great! Wasn't so impressed by the flea market part.

16.description: I saw this place on an episode of Man V. Food. It was advertised as an international market, but when we got there we were greeted by vendors selling office supplies, socks, tires and other "regular" flea market items. We were in and out in 20 mins and we were sooo glad we didn't have to pay for parking.

13.description: Great authentic food at great prices. What's better than a huitlacoche taco on a cold day? How about meñudo, freshly made and braising for hours. Lots of cool stuff you don't find in other places normally.

11.description: Expected something a little more upscale like the market in Charleston - not that the market in Charleston is the Taj Mahal or anything like that. Boy was I wrong.   Place is great if you need an overpriced Chinese knockoff  cell phone case or charger.  Maybe you want to consume  a fine meal from a filthy little taco vendor?   Better  double down on the Cipro before you do.   Couldn't flee here quick enough.

39.description: As some reviewers have mentioned, "this is not the Maxwell Street Market we all remember from years back, where it was bustling and you could find everything under the sun to purchase". We can all agree on that.  What I don't accept is that we regretfully must watch "the market's demise", hands in our pockets.If you want to preserve history, if want to see the old vibe return, then make it happen. Vote with your dollars, visit the Market, and visit more than Rubi's.If you value community, consider visiting or following the Maxwell Street Market Vendors Association, a group dedicated to the preservation and improvement of the market, at maxwellstvendors.wordpre… or facebook.com/MaxwellStVe…. In full disclosure, I'm affiliated with this group.You can also contact the department who runs the Market ([Commissioner] michelle.boone@cityofchi…), let them know what the Market meant or means to you, let them know that you aren't satisfied with the direction in which they've guided the Market, and what you think would help. Advertising maybe. Greater input from vendors maybe. It's up to you. In fact, this whole thing is up to you.

37.description: Have lived in Chicago for 5 years now and have never made it to this Street Market until today.  I loved it!  What a nice array of authentic Mexican food, fresh fruits and a wide range of things to buy from clothes to jewelry and a wide range of many other things.  My favorite was trying out Rudi's Mexican food.  The line was very long but so worth the wait.  Was fun to watch them make the tacos from scratch.  Incredible!  Was so good.  Looking forward to coming back here and spending a little more time.

0.description: Flea market spectaculaire!! Best flea market food and goods in town. I am marrying the man of my dreams after spending the summer wandering through his favorite Sunday hangout, The Maxwell Street Market. Discovering the best chotchkies and eating the best tacos I have ever had. If you haven't been, you're missing out!!!!

38.description: Love a good market...and this place is very good! A Chicago original...1) Open air market2) Easy to access by car (and park!) or public transit.3) Clean, safe, friendly, and interesting!4) A photographers mecca. 5) Food and drink options galore!6) New stuff, old stuff, used stuff, questionable stuff, food stuff, fashion stuff, phone  stuff...lots of stuff!7) Deluxe people watching8) Cash only!9) Colors, smells, music, impromptu salsa lessons, a fun leisurely walk about!10) Only on Sundays from April till November, 9am - 2pm. In my book, it darn near qualifies as church.

51.description: I have been here for years, coming with my mom from Indiana to get items for her store. I love this market. We usually come on Sundays around 1PM. May mom get great deals on purses and jewelry during 1-3PM. There are usually two street full of vendors during the summer with products such as food, produce, clothing, perfume, accessories, bikes and other items. In the summer, they also have a live band come to perform (or maybe this is also a vendor?). I love coming out here with my mom. Just not in the summer it can get hot and sunny, so bring a hat (or buy one).I came today to get a few a winter items and a purse. They are open in the winter, but note the vendors are few and between due to the cold/snow/rain. They only had one street blocked off (vs two-three in the summer). Most vendors where food, produce,  perfume and winter items. There were no purse vendor this day, but i did get a wool hat and some leather gloves for cheap! Guess I have to wait until Spring for most vendors to return. Overall, this is the spot in the summer/fall to get some great deals. I would suggest any person who likes to stay in style to come check it out for some deals. Bring cash, thought there are banks and ATMs in the area. I love this place!

27.description: I've lived in the Printer's Row area for about four years now, yet I never went to this Market despite it being only a ten minute walk away from where I live.What was I waiting for?!Only open on Sunday mornings during warmer months, you can spend a whole lot of time at this Market which is not actually on Maxwell Street (anymore). Obviously, you can't go wrong with eating food. It's kind of hard to describe the stands since many of them don't even have names, but you've got to get pork tacos from Rubi's, filled churros from the churro truck, and goat tacos from...this one place that advertises $1.75 tacos. Ok, it's really hard to describe, but you can't really go wrong anywhere here as long as you like Mexican.Other than the food, it's just fun to see the crazy stuff people put up for sale. There's the table with just belts. Or the tables with just shoelaces. Or the family selling expired snacks at a crazy discount. Yes, you can find some random deals here and there, but caveat emptor - you're not likely to ever get a refund or exchange, so don't spend more on something than you're willing to lose out of your pocket.I was shopping for an AC adapter since one of mine broke, and of course I found at least three guys with tables full of random power adapters. I eventually found one that worked for $6 (don't be afraid to haggle!), something that would've cost me over $10 on Amazon.The MSM is so great that it's not even some kind of special event for me anymore - it's more of a place to pick up some great produce, tasty food, and whatever random knick-knacks I need at home. A fun way to spend your weekend.

32.description: This is a review for Calvillo's- a great family owned Mexican restaurant at Maxwell Street Market.  My friend Marcia visited from London.  I got her down to the market on Sunday to try some authentic Mexican street food.We split a huarache, or masa flatbread, topped with pork al pastor, bacon-y and rich, with a sweet touch of tropical fruit.  She got a tangy quesadilla filled with squash blossoms.  I got a pambosa- basically potato and chorizo torta drenched in roasted tomato sauce and fried.  We split elote- kernels of sweet corn topped with a thick cap of mayo, lime and chile.For dessert we split a styrofoam cup of champurrado- Mexican hot chocolate thickened with corn masa into the thickness of a hot milkshake.  It warmed our hands and bellies while we strolled the market.

54.description: Note to self. Go to market with people who know where to find the best grub.I went with a friend who basically visits just to walk around. Not to check out the goodies. So when I asked what should we eat, he really was clueless and we just sat at the least busy taco stand even though I really wanted the handmade tortillas across the way. The food we had was decent but didn't blow my mind.I must say, there was tons of fresh fruits and veggies, nuts, seeds, electronics, knock off purses, you name it, someone there's gots it. I expected that the space would be bigger than it was. It's basically seemed like a couple city blocks with jam packed stuff.  I'd go again, but would try and avoid rainy days since the day I went there was so much rain, I ended losing my car keys down a sewer drain. Talk about an expensive outing.

48.description: The food is the closest to my mom's home cooking as I have ever found. Seriously...

44.description: to experienced junkers and antique collectors, the new maxwell street market hardly resembles the old one.  there are still a few bargains to be found (batteries, chewing gum and fake designer fragrances), but street food has stolen the show.  more specifically, TACOS are king!!!for my money, there's only one place to eat...  Rubi's Tacos is located right in the heart of the market.  you'll know it by the long line.  this isn't just the best street food in chicago, these are the best tacos you'll ever eat.  fresh, handmade tortillas, and a wide variety of authentic regional fillings like zucchini flowers (flor de calabasa), sauteed mushrooms (hongos), marinated pork (al pastor) and spicy stewed pork (mole).  add a large chunk of melted chihuahua cheese, transforming your taco into a quesadilla, and wash it all down with an ice cold mexican coke (they use real sugar, not corn syrup).this is chicago street food at its very best!

24.description: Authentic delicious Mexican street food goodness...I go for the food, nothing more.  There are plenty of options for the adventure eater looking to satiate a call for curious cuisine. So eat up.You can also go to buy what feel to be many stolen goods (and some handy crafts).

7.description: Fun outing on a lazy Sunday. This Maxwell Street Market is a replacement for the old one that was actually on Maxwell Street...on the south side of Roosevelt Road and a bit west of the Dan Ryan...all that was razed for the expansion of University of Illinois Chicago. This new version is on the north side of Roosevelt Road and on the east side of the Dan Ryan. The new Maxwell Street Market is on Des Plaines Street (the first street east of the Dan Ryan) and goes from Roosevelt Road (12th Street) north to Polk Street.The market is about two-thirds seeming garage sale and one third food stands. We like to walk by all the stuff but mainly focus on the food stands which are great. Just about all Latin American food - some Mexican (tacos and the like), some Salvadoran (papusas and the like), etc. Manolos Taqueira, Rubi's, and our favorite Mama Lula's for papusas (see Yelp comments on all of these). One of these Sunday mornings when you've nothing to do, give this place a try. While it is not the old Maxwell Street filled with Jewish merchants, it is still a fun and inexpensive outing.

49.description: 4 stars? Are you for real?!The only saving grace of this place is its' half way decent street taco vendors and that they sell really cheap packs of condoms.Fake luxury handbags, random car parts, seriously cheap packs of condoms (though questionable since they are in the sun for hours), over the counter meds, the list goes on. Whatever random stuff you could find at the La Puente Swap Meet, trust me, you'll find it at the Maxwell Street Market. Upon walking up to the street market, we expected to see a hipster street fair. You know..crafty street vendors, creative foods. Kind of like your local farmer's market. We were somewhat unpleasantly surprised though when we stumbled along this place. The fact that it's Chicago's Top Must See Place is shocking and we even had to confirm with the Firefighters parked out front that we were indeed in the right place. And unfortunately, we were.As I said, only thing worth visiting here is their Street Taco Vendors. I don't think I truly understood how lucky I am to be living in SD with the best Mexican Food until I came here. The food does the trick since Chicago doesn't seem to have many Mexican eateries and this actually the best place to go for authentic food so, I guess it does the trick. Hardly as impressive as its' made out to be.

40.description: This is not the Maxwell Street Market we all remember from years back, where it was bustling and you could find everything under the sun to purchase. These days it is much smaller, with the focus on food moreso than products and the grumblings of vendors complaining about the city "pushing them around" with high fees. While I was sad to see the market's demise, Rubi's is going to keep me coming back.So, this 5-star review is for Rubi's (the only reason we will be heading back to the market!).Yes, yes, yes! Yep, that is what you will hear from Mr. Rubi calling out to summon customers to Rubi's at the market while simultaneously sharpening the knives to cut the al pastor meat to perfection. And that is the same thing I left thinking when I finished my early lunch at Rubi's this past Sunday.Open from 7am-3pm every Sunday, Rubi's has some of the tastiest tacos and quesadillas I have ever tasted. I am really picky when it comes to Mexican food and even my mom that is an amazing cook was impressed. Where to begin?There is a vast selection of taco and quesadilla choices; certainly goes beyond your usual al pastor and steak. Options include mushroom, huitlacoche (corn fungus), rajas (sliced grilled jalapenos), mole and many many more. All are served in a big, fresh and tasty homemade tortilla that is made right before your eyes. I opted for a carne asada taco with cactus and a quesadilla con rajas (grilled peppers). Both were topped with onion and cilantro and with the green and red salsa on the tables, I was in heaven.The tacos and quesadilla were not greasy, huge portions, and tasted extremely fresh. I loved that the tacos were topped off with a grilled cebollitas. I cannot wait to go back and try the al pastor, and the tacos with huitlacoche, as well as the mole rojo taco. You can only eat so many tacos - believe me, picking out what to order was the hardest decision I made all day.I also noticed that this was one of the cleanest places to eat at the entire market. I also liked that unlike some of the other stands, they have one person that focuses specifically on taking your order and handling the money. I really appreciate that they have hand sanitizer available too & the utensils and napkins were well-stocked.The woman working there (maybe she was Rubi herself?) told my mom that when they don't sell out (which is rare) they eat the food themselves or give it away; never freezing it using it the next week. We believe her - everything was so fresh and tasty. No mysterious vats of ingredients; you can see everything being made and grilled right in front of you.Rubi's has just vaulted up to my #1 favorite taco place in the city and is the sole reason I will be making the trek out to Maxwell Street Market (well them and for the churros). Maybe it is not so bad that they do not have a restaurant and we have to wait to partake in deliciousness only once a week on Sundays at the New Maxwell Street Market, otherwise I'm thinking my waistline would be vastly expanded.Do yourself a favor and head to Rubi's on Sundays - but get there early, they close at 3PM but often sell out before that!

53.description: The listing is incorrect on Yelp. The new Maxwell Street Market is actually located on Des Plaines St. between Harrison and Roosevelt. The weather was not cooperating today as it was dreary and wet. So, I believe that some of the vendors were not really there. Anyhow, looking at the stuff that they have, your best bet is for the hats that they have. They were selling cologne and perfume, but I do not know if I can trust the knock off stuff as they perhaps may give you a rash. I was hoping that they had some knock off caps but I really didn't see much of that.There were several taco stands during my walk. Those were pretty interesting, although I have to say that you can get the same food at a Taqueria anywhere in Chicago. I think the only thing that you could not get readily at a Taqueria are the funnel cakes. I didn't see any artwork during my walk.I commend these people for actually opening up on a rainy day. I wish I could have found something to buy, but most of this stuff, you probably can go to the dollar store to purchase.

30.description: Outdoor flea market with all sorts of knick knacks and junk.  However, I try to stop by every few Sundays because you can get a great deal on fresh fruits and vegetables.  I got a huge bushel of tomatoes and red peppers for $10 and made a fresh marinara sauce that I ate so fast that I barely had any to freeze.  Every week there are different fruits and vegetables available, and sometimes the vendors don't come in the cold of winter.  Get together with some friends, or plan to cook something that will freeze well, because everything they sell is at the peak of freshness, meaning it will begin to go bad by mid-week.  I recommend getting plenty of their fresh strawberries and cutting the stems off and freezing for fresh summer smoothies.

46.description: For what it is, 5 stars.  Cheap churros, cheap tacos, authentic salsa, glass bottle sodas.  The food is great, but don't forget to check out the cheap hardware stands, 'used' stereo equipment vendors, children's clothing/toys as well as hygiene products.

1.description: So happy we decided to sneak on down here to get this real Chicago local experience. On most days you can find any and everything you could ever want at any if the many vendor stalls here at the market. The best part of this market is all the food vendors. This is a true Chicago mecca for some of the best and authentic Mexican street food. From the this to the quesadillas you can't go wrong... Trust me!!! This was some of the best carnitas and tacos el pastor I have ever had!!! Make it a point to visit this place walk around and enjoy a taco or two you won't go wrong...

55.description: Seriously, who gives this good reviews? I went thinking it was going to have things like books, veggies, flowers... Only to find its like a flea market with vendors selling stolen goods, deodorant and cheap scarves. The food places were packed but I don't like Mexican and that's all they served. In a sketchy part of town too. Stay away!

9.description: HISTORIC SUNDAY SHOPPINGI feel like I've grown up visiting this market since I was a little child. In fact, I've actually followed this Sunday market as it's been displaced by the city to three different locations over the years. The original location was located actually on Maxwell Street and Halsted. Starting around the 1880's, Eastern Europeans became the dominant ethnicity in the hood here. During this same time the open-air pushcart market appeared, which eventually made this neighborhood famous for deals, shopping & goods from around the world. Over this long history the neighborhood has changed along with the different ethnicities that have called it home but one thing remained. This market was a place where everyone in the city could come together and shop. There were no ethnic lines or judgements. Everyone was bonded by one common goal...to get a good deal. When I was a little a trip to this iconic street was not complete without a visit to Jim's for a Maxwell Street polish. I believe this is the birth place of the Chicago style polish. As you walked up to Maxwell Street, all you could smell were onions grilling. In fact, if I close my eyes I can still smell them now. Yum!I was really mad at the University of Illinois at Chicago for stepping in and ruining this Chicago tradition. In 1994 they slapped an eminent domaine on Maxwell Street Market, in order to take there property for themselves. Some things were not meant to be torn down and thanks to UiC we lost a piece of Chicago tradition because of greed. Luckily the city recognized the rich tradition the market played in our history and relocated it a few blocks east to Canal Street. It was also renamed the "New Maxwell Street Market". Unfortunately the market was no longer in Maxwell Street. Also the delicious smell of Jim's onions were also forced to move. Thanks UIC...NOT...as I'm shaking my head. Jim's Maxwell Street Polish is actually closer to his original location then the market is. He was moved over to Roosevelt Rd and the frontage road of the expressway. There's nothing like a polish with onions over there. A visit to Jim's reminds me of being a child visiting the original Maxwell Street on a Sunday. The new location was okay but lacked any feel of tradition that the old Maxwell Street contained. Then in 2008, Maxwell was forced to relocate again to Des Plaines Avenue. I blame Dominick's for this. They complained that the Sunday market was ruining there business. Let's recap...Dominick's said it was ruining there business...where is Dominick's now? Gone! If anything ruined Dominick's it was Safeway. Again another Chicago tradition that will be gone forever. RIP Dominick's. My point is we need to stop messing with a Chicago tradition or it will just disappear. I hope that this will be the final home for the famous open air market. The city has even erected medal structures on each corner to signify the markets existence. The market has changed over time but you never know what you are going to find. Also come hungry because the Jim's Polish dogs have been replaced with steak tacos. Yeah there is still the smell of onions in the air but its a different smell. Shopping and food go hand in hand. My brother taught me a valuable lesson about Maxwell street. Get there as it opens, in fact, if the vendors are still setting up their tables that's even better. They are eager to make their first sale, so you have the negotiating power to getting a good deal. Also, don't take the first price. You are suppose to haggle that's how people shopped before price tags. I also want to share a piece of market etiquette that you should use while shopping. Please do not walk up in the middle of my price negotiation with a vendor and then try to out bid me. This is not an auction. I was here first...walk away and find your own deal. This is the most annoying thing ever. It happens more when it's crowded and is really uncool. So have some respect to the process and negotiate your own deal. Maxwell Street has been around for a long time. It is part of our history and I hope it has a long run at the new location. Everyone loves a market. I am glad that Chicago has a place where all ethnicities can join together in a common bond of shopping for great deals.

26.description: Wow!! Tons of taco stands. Yum!! And the blue truck rolling out churros is the perfect finish.

25.description: Just a fun place to go and walk around, people watch, search for bargains, and grab a good taco or churro.  The whole atmosphere has really changed over the years and it seems like it is a huge tourist spot now.  It is also (in my opinion) a lot safer than it had previously been.  There is street parking available if you look for it.

12.description: Seriously this market has everything you will ever need! Need a charger...got that...need toothpaste...got that...need tires...got that .....need produce...got that...need lunch or brunch...got that!This wonderful gem is not far from my place and I always look forward to going every Sunday morning. The MSM has a great variety of sellers and pretty much something for everybody. For people like me who are post it note junkies and pen junkies, there is a guy who sells nothing but post it notes, pens, markers, and other office supplies.  There are few other stands that sell socks, socks, and more socks. Not going to lie, this stand comes in handy since I mysteriously loose socks after putting them in the dryer. There are a few produce stands with produce cheaper than the grocery stores. Bonus points: cheap avocados, cilantro, and tomatillo. The best part of this place is the food!! Yes, the food!! My personal favourite and I could seriously eat 1,000 of these are the Oaxacan tamales. These tamales are huuuugge! Don't confuse these with your average tamales. These Oaxacan tamales are wrapped in banana leafs and filled with salsa verde, chicken and cheese. These tamales are  soft, buttery, and rich in flavor. These bad boys can feed two people for the price of three bucks. Then there is Rubi's, which is everybody's favorite. They are good and well worth the wait. Remember to get the grilled onions. Then there are several stands that sell goat tacos,soup and tortas. YUMMMM!! Goat can taste quite gamey. However, if cooked right, it will leave you wanting more. There are so many great places to eat here that I could probably spend the next few hours talking about it. If you haven't been to MSM...you should definitely go!

59.description: For once, I didn't go out drinking until all hours of the night Saturday night and was up early, so I thought I'd finally wander over to Maxwell Street and see what the hubbub was.I walked up and down the market both ways.  What did I find?Detritus.Bad things happen when you don't stay out all night Saturday night and then get up early on Sunday morning.  Never again.  I'd rather have the hangover.  Uno star.

21.description: Good way to spend your Sunday morning. Great place to bargain. I bought GTA5 for $35! And of course who could say no to some greasy tacos after all that deal making but what made my day was a made to order churro I bought off a food truck. Best churro I have ever had in my life!! And it was only $1.25. I would suggest only carrying a certain amount of cash and leaving the credit cards at home (unless you have self-control) I spent all the cash I had on me and found myself looking for an atm every other stand. If you go late at around 2pm, when everyone is closing up shop, they're more likely to negotiate and bring down prices.

17.description: I've lived in the Printer's Row area for about four years now, yet I never went to this Market despite it being only a ten minute walk away from where I live.What was I waiting for?!Only open on Sunday mornings during warmer months, you can spend a whole lot of time at this Market which is not actually on Maxwell Street (anymore). Obviously, you can't go wrong with eating food. It's kind of hard to describe the stands since many of them don't even have names, but you've got to get pork tacos from Rubi's, filled churros from the churro truck, and goat tacos from...this one place that advertises $1.75 tacos. Ok, it's really hard to describe, but you can't really go wrong anywhere here as long as you like Mexican.Other than the food, it's just fun to see the crazy stuff people put up for sale. There's the table with just belts. Or the tables with just shoelaces. Or the family selling expired snacks at a crazy discount. Yes, you can find some random deals here and there, but caveat emptor - you're not likely to ever get a refund or exchange, so don't spend more on something than you're willing to lose out of your pocket.I was shopping for an AC adapter since one of mine broke, and of course I found at least three guys with tables full of random power adapters. I eventually found one that worked for $6 (don't be afraid to haggle!), something that would've cost me over $10 on Amazon.The MSM is so great that it's not even some kind of special event for me anymore - it's more of a place to pick up some great produce, tasty food, and whatever random knick-knacks I need at home. A fun way to spend your weekend.

10.description: Definitely worth checking out for local street eats and flea market merchandise.The foods are overwhelmingly Mexican, cheap, and tasty. Street vendor like food. It's not for everyone.The merchandise has some garbage (e.g., used shoes) and some pretty good deals. Caveat emptor as pretty much everything is sold as-is where-is.

5.description: This place has become one of my favorite Sunday morning activities. I definitely come here for their food and homemade tortillas. I like to food hop and try a little bit of food from the vendors from barbacoa tacos to gigantic quesadillas!

3.description: So there's a lot of history with the Maxwell St Market. This is a huge flea market with a ton of food vendors. There's a little bit of everything here, such as tires, boots, toys and even some food items. It's a large market area, taking up from Roosevelt to past Taylor.     There's a section consisting of just food venues, all Latin based. So you have your taco's empanada's tamales and more. They all looked tasty and there were lines for a majority of them. If you've got the time grab a bite and check out the crowds, if anything it's fun people watching

35.description: After seeing the Chicago episode of Bizarre Foods with Andrew Zimmern and a hearty endorsement from Rick Bayless, I knew had to make a pilgrimage to the Maxwell Street Market and experience what real Mexican street food had to offer. I wasn't disappointed. I don't remember the names of the stands we visited but we ran the gamut of street food until we could handle no more. The tamales were easily the best we had ever had and the taco selection is second to none. Fresh tortillas and el pastor being roasted on spits were highlights as well. One of our goals in this Mexican meeting ground was to try huitlacoche since we can't get anything like it in our hometown. We enjoyed it in a quesadilla and I was glad we did. Super earthy and sweet, I was instantly hooked and can't wait to try it again.There were fresh juices and coconuts and bunches of junk stands you would see at any flea market. With such an eclectic mix of vendors and people, I highly recommend the Maxwell Market to get a real flavor of Mexican cuisine and Chicago away from the typical touristy areas.

19.description: Authentic delicious Mexican street food goodness...I go for the food, nothing more.  There are plenty of options for the adventure eater looking to satiate a call for curious cuisine. So eat up.You can also go to buy what feel to be many stolen goods (and some handy crafts).

28.description: Maxwell Street Market, not much going on here unless you're a junk collector or like buying your underwear from an open market stall.  Lots of miscellaneous knick knacks from old records, new in box TVs, bikes, grocery items, etc.  Basically if you need something, you could probably find it at this flea market.  It's not very large but you could walk right through this thing in about 30 minutes or less.  The real gem however is the food section.

45.description: I miss you Chicago. Although I've only been with you twice you..you are my third mistress (SF is mistress #1, NY #2 and LA is my main biatch). I can't wait to see you again if only you were closer to CA. Now to be more specific and to touch on your best qualities...my top pick for food spots has to be Maxwelll Street Market...here you can find unique/niche mexican food while shopping for crap you don't need. This market reminds me of the swap meet/farmers market in Alemany (SF). I biked here from downtown through traffic like a mad man because my then gf wanted to visit EVERY museum and touristy attraction and this is only held one day on the weekends and we were only there for 5 days so there was no way I was gonna miss it. I almost got us killed biking there but boy was it worth it. If you visit Chicago...make time to go here...try any of the food stalls..pick one that's really busy. Order a taco or torta ahogada. BUT GO HUNGRY!!

33.description: We had a blast for a Sunday Morning tool around the city.  Something different.  The vendors were reasonable. The food was phenomenal.  I had my first tamale and the vendor was so excited he had me try all for FREE! I will never eat a Tom Tom again what a treat.  then the churro truck I am a vanilla girl tried the chocolate but hands down sugar sweet and warm vanilla custard DELICIOUS! We then ventured to the Harchata a tortilla stuffed with refried beans are you kidding me there is a Mexican God listening to my prayers LOL.  Its just like a taco but with beans and very very filling.  We also strolled around purchased some perfume that was $80 cheaper than in the store and when we got it home matches my bottle and the smell is identical.  I can't wait to go back it was a little cold but other than that had a great Sunday and tried some wonderful and delicious new food.

43.description: I go to Maxwell Street for the exercise, fresh air, mingling and the food.  It reminds me of the outdoor markets in Asia and Europe, but with Mexican and African American vendors.  The fact that it is an old Chicago staple of years past and a thriving and changing one at that is a testament to how we can all live together.  I also love the adventure of a good treasure and junk hunt (more junk less treasure), but really, I go for the tongue tacos.  I eat until I want to cry from pain, and then, I walk it off.  If I buy nothing else the whole time I'm there, I pick-up fresh fruit, a bag of dry chili and tamarind candy and go home happy as a clam.  FYI to construction companies - this is where the stolen tools and inventory from your warehouse ends up so after you make your insurance claim and collect the insurance money, come buy back your stuff here!

2.description: I have to give Maxwell Street Market four stars because of not only the historical significance, but also because this flea market has the best food options of any flea market I've visited.  The elote in a cup was probably my favorite part of our trip here.The merchandise and vendors rank somewhere between 2-3 stars.  There were some "junk" vendors with lots of random tools, household decor, and kitchen appliances, which are usually my favorites.  I purchased a set of porcelain coffee mugs made in France for $8.  They're looking pretty cute next to my Keurig!Other vendors include the infamous socks and underwear, toys, bath & body products, jewelry, soccer balls and t-shirts, and office supplies.  Nothing looked "hot" to me, but much of it screamed "overstock," because how on earth does someone have 20 bottles of Dove body wash to sell?Prices are not phenomenal.  My dad tried to negotiate with a vendor on a set of sockets.  The vendor went down a whopping $1.  Another vendor wasn't flexible at all on a pack of Sharpie pens.  That's cool, dude.  I'll spend a few bucks more at Staples where they're guaranteed to work or I can return them.We spent about 2-3 hours here, walking around, shopping, and eating.  Almost half of the market was vendors selling tacos, tortas, elote, horchata, churros, etc.  Food is cheap.  You MUST eat at the market if you come.We got here shortly after opening.  I don't feel that we got any better deals, but my mom raved about how much open space there was to walk around.  No worries about strollers being jammed into your heels at Maxwell.  Even as it got later, there was still plenty of open space, and even some dogs too!There's tons of street parking in the area.  Because I'm sometimes just an ignorant suburbanite, I couldn't remember if we had to pay for parking on Sundays.  Well, if you do, it's $4/hour.  If you don't, it's $0.  I shelled out the $4 for the first hour out of fear.  YOU'RE WELCOME, RAHM.

18.description: This is a review of the fair, not the food: I stumbled on the fair biking one day on the way to lunch.   It was bigger than I expected spanning a couple street turns and crossings.  However after walking through several booths I was unimpressed with the piles of cheap item, expired goods, and poor quality.    However I fully realize that this is a treasure trove to many people, it is just not my kind of thing.  I will have to come back for the food which seems to be highly reviewed!   Nice for people watching and experiencing another Chicago tradition, as watered down as it may be in 2014

41.description: This 5 star review is ONLY due to Rubi's! Pretty much the only reason I'll ever go back to the Maxwell Street Market is simply for the quesadillas at Rubi's - so delish! The steak was so tender and the homemade tortilla (which they make right in front of you) is to die for. We tried one of the red sauces they have on the tables and it was SO good too. I ate my quesadilla only 3 hours ago and I'm now craving another one.The rest of the market is well... your typical flea market with lots of junk that was likely stolen from somewhere.  And it seemed that today, everybody was selling socks. Lots of socks! Anyhow... Rubi's rocks!

52.description: we love maxwell street...my husband and i have lived in chicago for 3years now and we have a 2 year old little girl..we love going to maxwell and checking out all the cool things they have..yay they have alot of knock off stuff but were not going for that..we like the more flea market used things..its fun to find old items and get them for a dealwe dont normally eat from the food venders as were vegetarians and the options are pretty slim..we buy some produce there cause its pretty cheap and you get alot!we love that its all year around! even though the best time to go is in the summer when most venders are out..but its cool that it goes on even in the wintersometimes there are guys dressed as clowns and they make ballon animals for the kids(for a small price) sometimes there are dancers who have a reserved spot and dance for tips...and sometimes there are people who have a spot and their band plays..its tons of fun...it normally takes about a hour to walk threw and see everything (unless your really searching!)maxwell street is just a fun place for us to go and hangout when were bored on sunday mornings..our daughter loves going and looking at the stuff,she loves listening to the music playing..and since your able to bargain with some venders it makes the shopping experiences fun (or bad..depends LOL)

50.description: You'll find the best authentic Mexican street food in all of the midwest on the weekends here. Dreaming of the freshly made churros and tacos now.

4.description: Great flea market to eat authentic Mexican food and churros! I tried churros that were filled with vanilla and chocolate. They also have strawberry to choose from or plain. I was wishing for some dulce de leche. Nonetheless, the vanilla and chocolate churros were very good. I also had a tongue and pastor taco. The tortillas were freshly made and delicious. The pastor was moist and full of flavor; some of the best pastor I have had. The tongue wasn't bad but it wasn't the best u have had. Their green sauce was very good.

6.description: The food: 2.5/5. Great homemade tortillas. Tacos are cheap but fairy bland, particularly the beef tongue. If you're going to Maxwell Market for the food only, it doesn't warrant a trip there.

22.description: This Sunday market is world class.  What makes a street market world class?1.  It has to be open every week. 2.  You have to be able to go every week and still enjoy it.3. You don't have to buy anything to enjoy it, but you will always buy something.  4.  The food is awesome.MSM rates high on all four measures.  The nay-sayers are nay-seers.  They don't see what is going on here behind the piles of new, cheap merchandise.  The vendors here are not slaves to consistency. The guy selling tools will also have a pile of his grandma's costume jewelry for sale. The sock seller will have a rare book or two. Last week a guy selling computer parts had "a 1920's washing machine plunger" that was larger than most Chicago apartments ($20).  There are plenty of vintage items and collectibles. You just have to look for the off-beat stuff, it may not jump out at you. The vendors are nice, and make deals.  And the Mexican street food is beyond authentic, tasty and fresh, all prepared by hand on the spot. Lunch for $4-$5. Every variety, you can try something new each time. Tacos, gorditas, hurachas, quesadillas. Find the churro truck that fills your still warm churros with chocolate or raspberry. Sit at a large communal table with some families and have top notch grub with no attitude. If you like Mexican food, take a break from Rick Bayless and hang with the people who taught him what he knows. If you want to know what you're eating, you can learn Spanish; otherwise just point.

15.description: This Sunday market is world class.  What makes a street market world class?1.  It has to be open every week. 2.  You have to be able to go every week and still enjoy it.3. You don't have to buy anything to enjoy it, but you will always buy something.  4.  The food is awesome.MSM rates high on all four measures.  The nay-sayers are nay-seers.  They don't see what is going on here behind the piles of new, cheap merchandise.  The vendors here are not slaves to consistency. The guy selling tools will also have a pile of his grandma's costume jewelry for sale. The sock seller will have a rare book or two. Last week a guy selling computer parts had "a 1920's washing machine plunger" that was larger than most Chicago apartments ($20).  There are plenty of vintage items and collectibles. You just have to look for the off-beat stuff, it may not jump out at you. The vendors are nice, and make deals.  And the Mexican street food is beyond authentic, tasty and fresh, all prepared by hand on the spot. Lunch for $4-$5. Every variety, you can try something new each time. Tacos, gorditas, hurachas, quesadillas. Find the churro truck that fills your still warm churros with chocolate or raspberry. Sit at a large communal table with some families and have top notch grub with no attitude. If you like Mexican food, take a break from Rick Bayless and hang with the people who taught him what he knows. If you want to know what you're eating, you can learn Spanish; otherwise just point.

57.description: I'm from LA and so I'm used to the abundance of Mexican food.  I didn't think there would be such a big Latino population in Chicago until I came to this street market.  There are rows of stands selling all types of mexican food, ranging from tacos to quesadillas to horchata to anything you may crave.  Many of these stands make their tortilla from scratch too.  If I lived in Chicago, I would come here often to get my fix.When you come here, be sure to stop by the XOCO Churro truck.  They serve Rich Bayless' famous creme filled churros. I will tell you, you will regret it if you don't go here.  The vanilla creme churro was perfect.  I would've ordered more had I not had such a big lunch.

20.description: Great place to eat! Rubys tacos is where we had the authentic al pastor tacos marinaded with pineapple! This was a hidden gem! We also found the best stuffed churros there!!!

36.description: this place is cool! its a flea market with random house stuff plus good mexican food.tons of stands selling tacos, tamales, horchatas, quesadillas....etc etcsuper easy to get to by CTA.  got off blue line on clinton and walk 3 blocks.decided to try Rubi's tacos-lengua y al pastor.  tortillas were freshly hand made in the tent which was thick and delicious. tacos were huge as well ranging from $2.5-$3!

14.description: This is a review for Calvillo's- a great family owned Mexican restaurant at Maxwell Street Market.  My friend Marcia visited from London.  I got her down to the market on Sunday to try some authentic Mexican street food.We split a huarache, or masa flatbread, topped with pork al pastor, bacon-y and rich, with a sweet touch of tropical fruit.  She got a tangy quesadilla filled with squash blossoms.  I got a pambosa- basically potato and chorizo torta drenched in roasted tomato sauce and fried.  We split elote- kernels of sweet corn topped with a thick cap of mayo, lime and chile.For dessert we split a styrofoam cup of champurrado- Mexican hot chocolate thickened with corn masa into the thickness of a hot milkshake.  It warmed our hands and bellies while we strolled the market.

3.description: Standard hotel restaurant... nothing bad, nothing outstanding. When I traveled here, I was actually on a burger kick, so I had a cheeseburger from the menu. The burger was cooked to order (medium) and actually pretty big and good...but again, nothing made it bad per se, or outstanding either.The service is good here, even in the afternoon around check-in when it was fairly quiet. There's not much to look at or listen to if you're not in good company, so if you're rolling solo, take a good book I suppose. Pretty good hotel, and this is an A-ok, pretty good restaurant as well.

1.description: Simple menu but good food. Very friendly staff. Aware of their customers. Chicken parmigiana sandwich is very good.

2.description: AMAZING FOOD!  I stayed at the Marriott hotel with a friend for a concert.  The food was delicious and great portioned.  The prices were reasonable considering the area.  They were so good for dinner we returned for breakfast.  The staff and food was once again above our expectations.

5.description: Great atmosphere restaurant, The food was just excellent specially a salad named 625, the portion is amazing, the service was really good and dedicated, kudos for them. It is in perfect location specially if you are in the medical district area or UIC, also if you go to the restaurant they'll give you free valet parking for  2 hrs or something.

6.description: The food at Rooks Corner is pretty good. I love the buffets that they have each year on Easter and on Mother's Day. It's a great place to eat at with your family or friends.

7.description: Rooks corner is a hotel restaurant.  And the obvious focus in a hotel is to accommodate the weary traveler and provide a stiff late night drink.  That is why I only offer two stars for Rooks Corner in the Marriot on Ashland and Harrison. I ate here when my sister and her husband came to visit, and stayed at the Marriot. The coffee is good.  The service is good.My sister ordered the fried mozzarella balls with marinara and shredded parmesan.  They were standard, but the tomato sauce was a bit on the salty side, and a few of the balls were lukewarm in the center.     She also ordered a cheese and bread encrusted onion soup, and the soup was so salty she couldn't stomach eating the whole crock and returned it promptly.For my entree, I ordered the crab cake appetizer with a pink remoulade.  On the menu the crab cakes are noted as a healthy and light option -- since when is a mayo based sauce healthy?  At any rate, they were quite good.  My sisters barbeque chicken pizza had a zesty oven baked taste to it.  I would recommend the flatbread pizzas over anything on the menu here. They had a nice array of ingredients to build your own as well as some set options.I would never come out of my way to eat here, but it is a decent option if you're staying at the Marriot. Although, you might just want to drink for dinner.  The bartender was very jovial and seemed to really enjoy his job.

8.description: Very typical hotel restaurant. The food tries very hard to be fancy and creative but it really doesn't get there. The service was OK, the food was OK but for just OK the prices seem a bit out of line. My wife and I shared a hummus appetizer which was tasty and had a bit of veggies and a cut up pita. The hummus was unique in that there were a few deep fried chickpeas on top. That said, $9 at a casual dining restaurant seemed a bit much for it. I had a "wild" mushroom flatbread pizza. It was tasty though I question whether the De Chevre cheese really worked with the bitter tomato sauce. It also did not help that the mushrooms looked to be white button and crimini mushrooms. For $13 I would at least expect a little more effort. My wife had a salad with a salmon filet on top. The salmon was well cooked to a perfect medium-rare though it was completely bland. It really wasn't bad, but for the money I would definitely go elsewhere.

0.description: Amazing food and friendly staff!! Couldn't ask for more!!!!! Get the fries...you won't regret it!!!

4.description: A good breakfast for a simple selection of typical breakfast items: waffles, french toast, potatoes, cereal, and toast. The only reason I would come back is the lady that makes omelets. She is very nice and cordial. The food is alright all around, nothing special but fills you up in the morning.I've been here a few times and would still come back.

58.description: No one comes here.  Fine, that's not entirely true, but this location is wonderful compared to the hell that is the Clybourn location.  I've been in a number of Costco location and I still think this layout is weird, but I don't even care simply because it never seems like there is a crowd. Not much by way of organic produce (and I'm sure that's because they go by the demographic), but the employees here are much friendlier, easier to find and don't laugh at me when I ask for an item I'm standing in front of.I'm not positive that gas is cheaper than the Clybourn location, but I wouldn't doubt that sometimes this is the case.

56.description: Beautiful store and very friendly staff, but....  it was very crowded, which is a turnoff for me.  Maybe I just went on a busy day but I would return for sure.

29.description: This Costco is a lot like the Costco's in the suburbs (except for the one near Oakbrook Mall, which is terrible).  It's easy to get to from the West Loop, it has all of the usual stuff, and there's plenty of parking (pro tip: don't turn down the first or second row when you enter the lot).  Also, I like their pizza.

42.description: The super mega Costco on Ashland how I love you. I love to buy my produce here, it's fresh and jumbo size. Also a close favorite the mega liquor selection with all types of choices. They have plenty of parking and a friendly staff. Enjoy one of the nicest Costco's around.

23.description: Got my membership for this Costco when I moved here over the summer and I think, even though I maybe only go once a month or so, I've already earned back my membership's cost in savings. Between the great deals on gas, savings on products bought in bulk, and, of course, the delicious pizza and hotdogs at the food court, my experiences here have been nothing but good. Of course, it's a pain that there aren't any bags and you have to pay with a debit or check if you don't have an American Express card, but it's part of corporate deal, I guess. The free samples make up for it, if you get there early enough to grab 'em!

47.description: Its Costco, nuff said. Great prices on a ton of items and it's never crowded. I usually don't get produce here though, as that tends to get a little pricey. But for being in Chicago, I ain't complainin. The only thing I hate about it is how I have to take Ashland south to get there!

8.description: This place gets packed on the weekend (so I've been told) so it's best to try to get here during the week.  I've been here a few times with friends on weeknights (as I don't have a Costco card of my own) and it has all the regular things to expect from Costco.I've gotten everything from some nice rubber mats for the car to chocolate covered strawberries and moscato for a girls' night.  Food is good, everything is cheap, and they seriously have nearly everything.  In all earnestness, this is where you should block yourself in if there were ever to be a zombie uprising.My friend suggests always getting a cart, as even if you only get 2 items both of your arms are going to be full already and you won't be able to take advantage of any of their other bulk deals.

31.description: Having been a member of Sam's Club I figured I would give Costco a chance. I was pleasantly surprised at the similarities yet I had a feeling that here there was more organization or order with the exception of the food counter. I will get to that. The prices on electronics were more than competitively marked and were the latest releases. Browsing in the produce area shocked me at how high the beef prices were. I wonder if people just grab sometimes and don't take 5 seconds to compute what they are actually paying for things. $3.99 per lb for 80/20 ground beef is NOT a deal. Neither are $2.99 chicken breasts. Don't even bother buying ribeyes from here, like $13.89 lb WTF.. I could go on but won't. After buying a 10 year supply of fish oil and multivitamins I trekked over to the fast food counter and stood in 1 of 2 lines. When it was my turn I made eye contact with the clerk who promptly informed me that there was 1 line. Really I thought to myself after watching like 3 other people before get served. Okay, don't want to argue with people touching my food I thought. I now go directly to the end of line 1. My turn arrives and I order for the family and take the food to the table when I realize I forgot my son's slice of pizza. Darn! He (11 years old)gladly takes a $5 bill from dad and heads up to line #1 where he is like 4th in line. I glance over and the bitch that told me there was 1 line now announces "I can take your order here" ,opening a 2nd line, prompting what can be best described as a herd of puffy winter coat wearing adults and side stepping goofs to trample, butt, and talk over an 11 year old kid. I dropped my foot long hot dog and go rescue my guy. His 220lb dad walks up politely like  Leslie Nielsen youtube.com/watch?v=foll… and calmly handles the situation. A beautiful slice of cheese pizza with a side order of shredded puffy jacket.

34.description: My Daughters frame to her eyeglasses broke and I immediately called Costco's Optical Department with a couple questions. Answers were not the only thing they provided. I was so pleased with their employee Dan. He went above and beyond to help me find a Particular frame I was looking for which he said was sold out in the entire country. He took the initiative to look through other websites for the frame while talking to me on the phone, he was able to locate it in a different color and also have it shipped to costco within a timely manner. Within only 10mins he was able to get a sale and give me Awesome customer service!!!! He made my day a lot easier!!! Thanks again!!! ; )

16.description: We love this costco. We always been a member if costco. And since we live close to this location, it's like we automatically in love with this location.The parking is huge. Other cost of have huge parking, but for me, in this location, it's just easier to get parking near the entrance. (Trust me! 3 kids and only by myself, parking near entrance is just like I win a jackpot! )The cashiers, the greeters and the people who check go the stuff are super nice to me and my 3 kids. My kids are actually feel like costco is their second home.And since we go here more than twice a month, they actually know me (probably because my kids are obnoxious, love to scream that type of kids! Sorry Costco!).Anyway, costco is dear to my heart :)

13.description: I like this Costco way better than the Clybourn location, which is VERY crazy and hard to find parking.I have been coming to this Costco since June, and while it has gotten progressively busier, I still like this location. Slightly smaller and less selection than the Clybourn one. I try to limit the amount of time I am here, because you can end up buying the entire store...Gas station always has the lowest gas stations around. Lots of samples flowing, even at 2:30PM! *Be careful of some of the fruit, some of it that we have bought expires VERY quickly, especially the berries.

11.description: Costco, I love you. I love your inexpensive huge whole pizzas. Every time I buy one, I think, "oh yeah! I can totally eat this whole thing with just one other person!"Every time there is enough for at least two other people.This Costco's food court has made me pout by being so busy that they've messed up my pizza order about 3 times.Hopefully I'll learn my lesson and check my pizza before I leave the food court area.

39.description: The optometrist experience is terrible. The receptionist is not friendly, kind, understanding or helpful.

37.description: Why am I in Costco? I don't have children to buy diapers and formula for nor does my household have 20 members. Oh yeah...the wild caught sockeye salmon, seafood, beef selections(particularly the filet of beef), Starbucks Via packs and Dove body wash thats why! But what's funny is watching people run each other over getting to the samples. On a good same day I know at least 100 pairs of ankles are getting scraped and bruised! Some items are a bit pricey but I think you just have to be a savvy shopper. They also have a pretty good wine selection although it varies from store to store. I buy my tires here when needed and I have always received awesome service.

0.description: I love my local Costco,  the customer service is phenomenal! Went to return a gift,  the girls at the return were uber helpful but couldn't get the job done. Then came their boss Louie who tried the various permutations and combinations to find the day the product was purchased and got it all sorted in matter of minutes. Keep up the good work! !

38.description: It's hard not to love Costco.  Mountains and mountains of bulk food, electronics, and booze.  They have a great little concession stand/cafe.  The food ranges from pizza and dogs to soft serve and even churros.  Cash only but I think you can pay for the food with a CC at the checkout lines?It's hard to ever escape this store without dropping a few hundos.  My latest find was a 1.5 TB Seagate External hard drive for $79.99!  I can backup all 3 computers in my house with that bad boy and have plenty of room for the next.  Now this place doesn't always have exactly what your looking for so you'll still usually have to make a run to a normal grocery store.  Also it's really not reasonable to expect to purchase food for 2 either.  So plan out what your going to get and how your going to use it before you just go hog wild.  Of course this place has a great selection of large bottles of cheap booze.  This place can turn you into a lush in the blink of an eye.  Friendly tip:  if your a bourbon drinker try the Kirkland bourbon, word on the street is that makers mark makes this for Costco!

51.description: I love Costco. I'm here 3-4x a week, and I don't even work there.BTW - they don't take Visa or MC. Don't be my mom and write a freakin' check and make everyone behind you wait while they run a flippin' credit check. Amex, cash, or debit cards. If you write a check or try a Visa or MC and I'm behind you in line, you will get cussed out. Sorry, not sorry.BUT.... there's NO LEMON PLEDGE!!! (as of 15/Nov/2013) So I wrote them a letter and I thought I'd share this with you:Dear Costco,I am disappointed that no local stores (Chicago) seem to carry Lemon Pledge, yet I can order 3 cans from your Business Delivery website has it (item #650991) no problem, for $12.58 plus a $20 delivery surcharge. But the stores or regular national website don't carry plain old Lemon Pledge? I can't believe that there is no demand for the product. It's Lemon Pledge. I mean, there are jokes about it on Family Guy. Everybody has Lemon Pledge in their house.It really makes little sense to me. Your stores have all sorts of cleaning products (usually one branded one, and one Kirkland) but no furniture polish?I hope your buyers decide to stock this item. I will be a happier customer. And my furniture will be cleaner and shinier. Well, I mean, I still buy it... but since you don't carry it, I can't buy it at Costco. I buy it at Walgreen's. Costco, do you really want me spending my Lemon Pledge money at Walgreen's? I'd rather spend my money at Costco. I love Costco! But c'mon, Costco - show me a little love too. Stock some Lemon Pledge.

27.description: Costco, I love you. I love your inexpensive huge whole pizzas. Every time I buy one, I think, "oh yeah! I can totally eat this whole thing with just one other person!"Every time there is enough for at least two other people.This Costco's food court has made me pout by being so busy that they've messed up my pizza order about 3 times.Hopefully I'll learn my lesson and check my pizza before I leave the food court area.

32.description: First I'd like to say this relatively negative review is no reflection on the employees at the Ashland location, who I think are great.So it's great to have another Costco, but this review is entirely about pricing.  Specifically, why are the meat prices higher at this Ashland Costco location than at other Chicago Costco locations, and I am referring to the lower meat prices at the Ford City location (and read on for a note about the north side location).  This was definitely true as of about a year ago and it means that though this location is more convenient, I do not use it much, which is a shame.So I found this out one weekend day when I had to drive a lot and happened to be going by both the Cicero location and this Ashland location and I compared prices on the same day and found a selection of meat prices $1 to $2 *per pound* higher at this Costco, on Ashland.I did this little investigative work because I had believed there were price differences when this location first opened and thought maybe it was a fluke or mistake, but then I decided to actually record the prices.  I specifically checked rib eye, new york strip, and sirloin steaks.  So I asked about it and discovered this pricing manipulation that happens at Costco.  I asked the meat manager and he said there was no mistake.  There was no price change timing issue.  He explained this "competitive pricing" situation that only *some* of the Costcos have, and those will have better pricing.  He explained that it was not a mistake that their prices were higher than the price that I gave him from another Costco.  Initially I told them about this problem thinking that they just made a mistake and I was trying to help them fix it.Again, this was about a year ago, and due to it I don't really shop at this Ashland location much.As far as I proved, this was only on things like meat; however, I believe it applies also to dairy and eggs too? I didn't do A-B comparisons on those items though the same day.  I also believe it does *not* apply to any non-refrigerated food items, but that's just my impression.  But I do believe that grape juice that is in the aisles has the same price at all the Costco stores in the area.I know this does not affect the price of things like electronics since for one they frequently publish those prices in their coupon books.One further location detail, if I recall correctly the north side location also had lower pricing!  And that north side location has no Sam's Club near it, so not sure what's up there.  If anything you would think the north side location would have the high prices since it's in a much better area.So again I want to repeat that it's no fault of anyone who works here, and I've had very positive experiences at this location as far as customer service, but I think Costco should change their policy about this kind of pricing.  A Costco should be a Costco and that means being able to rely on pricing.  And I shouldn't have to investigate and compare prices with another Costco that is 5 miles away.  And also I'd like to know exactly how extensive these price differences store to store are.

54.description: I was the last hold out in my family to join Costco.  That was until I learned there was one near the South Loop with a gas station!!!  Awesome location, staff are both helpful and friendly.  After a recent purchase at Costco Optical for a second pair of glasses, I couldn't be happier.  They are actually better than the ones I purchased at a nearby vision center for a fraction of the price. Sold on this place all around.

48.description: Love having this place so much closer to me than the other Costco on Clybourn. Plus it is so much easier to get in and out of. The staff was friendly and helpful. Cheaper gas than the rest of the city is always a good thing.

44.description: I love this Costco. But I don't want to write this review because I'm selfish and don't want all of Chicago knowing that this location exists. So many people still think that there's only one location in the city and I want to keep this one for myself!A Costco that you can actually go to on the weekend without wanting your blow your brains out? Impossible, you say. NAY! This Costco isn't usually slamming busy and I've actually been there on a Saturday where there was NO LINE. Yes, you read that correctly. I love Costco especially for its great deals on organic produce and dairy and of course its killer deals on vino.It's super clean, staff are always helpful (and not impossible to find), and there is a gas station (super bonus) which is usually at least 10 to 20 cents per gallon cheaper than anywhere else in the area!Note: They only accept debit or Amex, and of course, cash. Don't be that person who is standing up at the front of the line with her checkbook out. I will zap you with my laser eyes. Come prepared!

24.description: I frequent this Costco for the food staples I can purchase and store in large quantities.  During the week it's never too busy and there are usually tons of free samples.  The weekend is another story, with crazy long lines and much fewer freebies.  There is a huge parking lot and I've never had any problems with the customer service. But, just a heads up that they don't sell diesel at the gas station.

7.description: What makes this Costco different? It has kimchi, dried seaweed, Chinese sausage, and other asian-friendly items. There's a Korean pork jerky (bbq style) near the front that you absolutely must try.If that hasn't drawn you in, then you have to become a member just for the cheap gas.

49.description: The place for GAS and everything you need in bulk.

40.description: I heart Costco. Back when it used to be called Price Club, I was already a fan. (Yup, I'm takin' it back to the ole skewl). The gas is cheap (score!), there are usually free samples of food handed out, and best of all...you can get a hot dog and fountain drink for only $1.50. That price has not changed since I can remember. I mean...who does that??!!~ COSTCO! That's who!!!Costco is consistent with the high quality of their products. If I see something on sale, or if I see a product from a brand I've never seen...I'm still confident that if I purchase it and try it out, it will be a great buy. Not only do we save money by shopping here, but it's such a great bargain for great quality products.When in doubt, just buy the Kirkland brand if there's a choice between that or another more well-known brand name. You really can't go wrong with it.

53.description: I'm glad this place was built since it's the closest to my house.  that being said, the only drawback with this location is the gas prices.  I buy gas exclusively from costco if I can help it, but this one is not cheap in that regard.  it's cheaper than lincoln park, but I typically get my fuel in melrose park or bedford park.  much cheaper.  orland park is cheaper as well.  but that is to be expected given this location is in the city.

30.description: I love Costco in general and I especially love this location! Luckily for me, this one is the closest to me. This location is fairly new and very clean. Workers are friendly and I normally find almost everything here that I came for. My favorite part of my membership is the cheap gas and food court.

46.description: I've been converted to a die hard Costco fun b/c of this location, its friendly & warm employees, its awesome selection of a relatively small amount of merchandise, and the fact that it's a one stop shop that takes care of all my household needs. Every single one of its product is of good quality - it takes uncertainty out of grocery shopping. What's more, I LOVE the brand and the philosophy behind it - great product for a great price, save money, live better, treats employees with respect (you can tell that the folks there love working there), and treat customers with the warmth and great service that no don't see in other big box national chain stores. I took one star off b/c today I had a chilling moment at the cashier when I was being checked out by Kevin (a young guy in his mid 20's) - it was "chilling" because his attitude made me feel like I was at a Wholefoods! i.e. not making eye contact with customer, chatting up with his fellow employee the whole time he was doing the ringing up. The only thing he didn't have was visible tattoos and nose rings.  I bought a box of Chinese pineapple cakes which he and his co-worker thought was delicious, and they were gasping about how delicious it was to each other, while it could have been a perfect opportunity to chat it up with the customer. It was pretty obvious that he did not care about the customers who were right in front of him. When I asked him out of curiosity "how many cakes are there in the box?" he pointed to the box first and said it doesn't say, and I pulled the box closer and wanted to check myself, so he made a second attempt by actually looking at the box and then told me: 16. This was such as different experience than before (I've never seen this guy before) -- normally every single one of the folks at this location is super friendly and helpful. They rightfully suggested us up-grading to executive membership given our spend; helped my husband getting air pumped into our car's wheels on a super snowy and cold day, etc. Their warmth made this Kevin guy's coldness stand out. Please, pelase, please dearest Costco, please do NOT become a Wholefoods type of brand, where employees get cocky and snobbish because of the great products it carries. Please do not allow employees to put up that air of "you are lucky to be shopping here". We are your fans. And for such a great brand, your employees should be greater fans of the brand than the customers. Don't you think?

1.description: If I could live in Costco then I would!! This place has everything you need and things you didn't know you need. Costco has it all..gas, oil changes, tires, vacation packages, pizza, Gouda, French wine, furniture, clothes...aw hell the list can go on! Yes, there is a small yearly membership fee one pays, but well worth it.  Their customer service is top notch and haven't came across any issues yet. I recommend hitting up their cafe...well pizza/hot dog corner...before shopping. For under $5 bucks you can feed 3 people....when was the last time you saw that in the city?!?  It helps to have food in your stomach cause otherwise you will be coming home with a box of mini tacos the size of Africa. Weekends are packed here, but they have samples like nobody business on the end of each aisle. We always get our steaks, chicken, and salmon from here since the prices are a steal. Other great items here to get are chips, booze, and household items. Like everyone has said the gas is the cheapest you will find in the area. I could rave about Costco for another 6 paragrahps, but you gotta just check  it out your self. Once you enter Costco shopping anywhere else will never be as great.

55.description: Costco, you are the greatest.  I swear you come in for some chicken and walk out with a big screen tv, couch, and a coat.    You cannot beat the prices here.  This location in particular has ample parking and lots of space to shop.  I actually come here more than the grocery store because there aren't long lines and the staff is nice and friendly.

9.description: Quick and easy. While I'm sure the corporate office wishes this place was busier, that is the benefit of going here. Still no where near as busy as the one on Lincoln Park. Get in, get out, get gas. What's not to love? Staff is overly friendly and  checkouts are always quick for the most part. Local traffic isn't bad so getting in and out of the parking lot is a snap.If you like Costco already, no reason not to go here.

26.description: I like this Costco way better than the Clybourn location, which is VERY crazy and hard to find parking.I have been coming to this Costco since June, and while it has gotten progressively busier, I still like this location. Slightly smaller and less selection than the Clybourn one. I try to limit the amount of time I am here, because you can end up buying the entire store...Gas station always has the lowest gas stations around. Lots of samples flowing, even at 2:30PM! *Be careful of some of the fruit, some of it that we have bought expires VERY quickly, especially the berries.

25.description: Hate the long lines! It's a CostCo...you know what to expect. I do love to get gas here as it's way cheaper than anywhere else.

12.description: I almost hate to review this location as I want to keep it my little secret.  I have been a member of Costco since they first ventured into the Chicago market. The first location was in Schaumburg, if memory serves. The location on Clybourn, is the closest to my house, yet I would rather have a colonoscopy than shop there. The Ashland location is fantastic, it's easy, in and out, the best of Chicago area Costco gas prices, great parking and friendly staff.  Perhaps the management at Ashland could provide some training to Clybourn and help them deal with the difficult clientele. Until then, I hope my favorite Costco continues to shine.

59.description: I like Costco.  I dont love Costco.This location is quite, hidden and not as crazy as the other one.  That is definitely a plus.  People dont push you out of the way to get things or samples.  Chill out crazy!  Also, there is ample parking here.I have to say, I honestly dont think that Costco has that great of prices...GASP!  I think they are ok.  When you look at the price per unit, you arent really saving anything buying mega portions of stuff.  I think if you have a large family...this might be a good place because of the bulk, but not for the prices.  For me, I personally like Aldi, Trader Joes or Mariano's way better and they both beat Costco on prices and I dont have to have a membership to them.I do think that this store is great.  It is clean, staff is nice, etc.  I just dont think that the prices are that great.

21.description: I love costco and I am so glad this is my costco. This Costco has a gas station, wine section, and tire shop. II've been to lots of costcos but this one has has plenty of parking and a gas line that is never very crowded.Love it.

17.description: I've been to this location 3 times, and 2 of the times something got screwed up. The first time I went, I bought gift cards, and it wasn't until some days later that I realized I was given the incorrect ones (lesson learned - if you buy gift card there, which can be a great value, check the envelope before walking away from the poorly staffed customer service desk). Tonight when I was leaving, they discovered one of the items in my cart hadn't been scanned and so I had to go back to have it properly rung up. I realize mistakes happen, but having been inconvenienced two out of the three times I've been here...I plan to avoid this location. The reason I didn't give it one star is that parking is more convenient than the other Chicago location.

10.description: If you live or visit this Costco frequently consider yourself blessed. This is the best Costco located in Chicago. First, their parking lot is HUGE (Donald Trump accent HUGE). They have two LARGE lots so there's far less stress (have you been to the Lincoln Park one?) when it comes to parking your automobile. Second, being one of the newer Costco's built in Chicago the interior food court is spacious and the interior feels less cramped than other stores. Third, there is a gas station and I've always had a friendly experience with their staff.

5.description: I love you Costco! But this review is for the 'Hearing Aids' center at this store. Excellent service, products and prices, and two amazing people who work there.  My father interacted with both specialists.  They were incredibly patient, and worked with him to find the right set of hearing aids. Also the 'Costco' brand here is top of the line.
